title: 107_s1541
content: The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" can be cited as the short title. Federal-State agreements are addressed in the act. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits under State law, without rights to compensation under any other State or Federal law, and not receiving compensation from Canada's unemployment law. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide additional benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular compensation under State law due to receiving all available payments or termination of rights. The weekly benefit amount is determined under this act. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide additional benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular compensation under State law. The compensation for total unemployment is equal to the regular compensation payable during the benefit year. State law terms and conditions apply to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, except where inconsistent with this act. The Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide additional benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular compensation under State law. The maximum amount of temporary emergency unemployment compensation payable to any individual shall not exceed the amount established in their account. Governors of states may elect to trigger off an extended compensation period. Governors of states are authorized to trigger an extended compensation period to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted their regular compensation under State law. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The State will establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account equal to 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year. The individual's temporary emergency unemployment compensation account will be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The weekly benefit amount is based on the regular compensation payable for total unemployment. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH AGREEMENTS FOR TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION. Payments will be made to states that have agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, equal to 100% of the compensation paid to individuals. States will not receive payment if they are entitled to reimbursement under any other federal law. Sums payable to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation will be determined by the Secretary and paid in advance or as reimbursement. The amounts will be based on the estimated entitlement for each calendar month, adjusted for any discrepancies found by the Secretary in prior estimates. The Secretary's estimates for prior calendar months may be adjusted if found to be inaccurate, using agreed-upon methods with the State agency. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds in the extended unemployment compensation account shall be used for payments to States with agreements under this title. The Secretary certifies sums payable to each State for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury. The extended unemployment compensation account will make payments to States as certified by the Secretary, transferring funds to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Appropriations are available to assist States in covering administration costs under this title, with additional funds authorized for certain payments from the Treasury's general fund. The extended unemployment compensation account receives appropriations from the Treasury's general fund without fiscal year limitation to make payments for specific types of compensation. These appropriations do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. If an individual knowingly makes a false statement or fails to disclose a material fact to receive unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation, they will be ineligible for further benefits according to state laws on fraud in unemployment claims. In cases where individuals wrongly receive emergency unemployment compensation, they must repay the amount to the State agency unless the agency determines the payment was not their fault. The State agency may recover overpayments by deducting from emergency unemployment compensation or other federal assistance if repayment is not the individual's fault and is against equity. The State agency may recover overpayments by deducting from emergency unemployment compensation or other federal assistance if repayment is not the individual's fault and is against equity. Repayment of any assistance or allowance with respect to any week of unemployment, within 3 years of receiving unauthorized payments, may not exceed 50% of the weekly benefit amount without a fair hearing. Any determination by a State agency under this section shall be subject to review in the same manner and to the same extent as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This title defines key terms such as compensation, benefit year, and week according to the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. An agreement under this Act applies to unemployment weeks starting after the agreement and ending within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE FOR STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUND ADVANCES. The rate of interest paid by a State on advances made under section 1201 of the Social Security Act will be reduced from 10 percent to 5 percent for a period of 18 months after the enactment of the Act.
